to test with:
# # client_id = "attestor-1"

text:
So:
``` curl -X POST \  <https://keycloak.dev.canton.ibtc.network/auth/realms/ibtc-catalyst-devnet/protocol/openid-connect/token> \  -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \  -d 'grant_type=client_credentials&client_id=attestor-1&client_secret=5ruw8QZkWXPSJI39zDWsid9O41cM4TSr'```
This returns a JWT that authenticates you to actAs and readAs the attestor-1 'user' and its primary party. We will set up a new keycloak client for this usecase

elements.text: So:
curl -X POST \
\  -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \  -d 'grant_type=client_credentials&client_id=attestor-1&client_secret=5ruw8QZkWXPSJI39zDWsid9O41cM4TSr'
This returns a JWT that authenticates you to actAs and readAs the attestor-1 'user' and its primary party. We will set up a new keycloak client for this usecase

text:
What would be the flow? So I can imagine something like:

1. We create a party.
2. Send that party ID out so someone can "reserve money on it."
3. We just periodically get all the parties and transfer X amount of CC token from that account?

We create a party.
Send that party ID out so someone can "reserve money on it."
We just periodically get all the parties and transfer X amount of CC token from that account?

text:
> Send that party ID out so someone can “reserve money on it.”
Yes, we need to keep a list somewhere of all the parties that match these claims (metadata) and what’s their partyId. SO that the business team can send that data to them

text: yes the API exists, and we can use it to bulk load up the current ones. But after that, I’m not sure our business team will use it as a tool, or if they’ll do it by hand. A tool would certainly be better

text:
Detailed Flow:
1. We create a party via the backend POST /party (or do it on a UI, so the BD team clicks on a New Party button)
2. Send that party ID out so someone can "reserve money on it."
3. The backend periodically get all the parties (annotated with te CBTC Holder and Early Bird) and transfer X amount of CC token from that account to the main operator of Bitsafe.

elements.text: Detailed Flow:
We create a party via the backend POST /party (or do it on a UI, so the BD team clicks on a New Party button)
Send that party ID out so someone can "reserve money on it."
The backend periodically get all the parties (annotated with te CBTC Holder and Early Bird) and transfer X amount of CC token from that account to the main operator of Bitsafe.

text:
Well, since I did not make a transfer yet, and I don't know how to get it I would say the flow what the periodic job does:
1. Get all annotated parties in every 10 min.
2. Get the last transfer of the party. 
3. Calculate the amount what we should transfer based on the time between last transfer and now.
4. Make the transfer.

elements.text: Well, since I did not make a transfer yet, and I don't know how to get it I would say the flow what the periodic job does:
Get all annotated parties in every 10 min.
Get the last transfer of the party.
Calculate the amount what we should transfer based on the time between last transfer and now.
Make the transfer.

text: Yeah i think that makes the most sense.

elements.text: Yeah i think that makes the most sense.

text:
I wouldn't do the frequency into the annotation, because the job would likely to run in every 10 min. So it's just confuses the syncronhization.
I would say put the amount into the annotation and we assume it's a 10 interval amount and we just calculate based on that. For example if the last transfer was like 30 minutes ago, than we can 3x amount.

elements.text:
I wouldn't do the frequency into the annotation, because the job would likely to run in every 10 min. So it's just confuses the syncronhization.
I would say put the amount into the annotation and we assume it's a 10 interval amount and we just calculate based on that. For example if the last transfer was like 30 minutes ago, than we can 3x amount.

text:
i guess an interesting question is, if we do miss a billing cycle, should we send the 3x $ in one big tx, or rather 3 little txs. But that’s also unrelated.

Actually I think our solutions are basically the same, they both can be run on whatever time interval we want. But if we put the billing frequency in the annotation, in theory we can change it dynamically per credential

text:
I feel like they are the same solution actually.

In one case, we pull the parties, check their CC transfers, and see if it’s been 10 minutes.

In the other case, we pull the parties, check their CC transfers, and see if it’s been “paymentFrequency” minutes.

text:
so <@U093Q4FPEJG> I noticed that if it runs more often than 10 minutes, it will bill in that smaller time interval. My vision was that if it ran every 2 minutes, it would detect that it hadn’t been 10 minutes since the last payment, so it wouldn’t bill anything until it detects more than 10 had passed.

Anyway, we can think about it later, this should work for now

elements.text: so

I noticed that if it runs more often than 10 minutes, it will bill in that smaller time interval. My vision was that if it ran every 2 minutes, it would detect that it hadn’t been 10 minutes since the last payment, so it wouldn’t bill anything until it detects more than 10 had passed.

Anyway, we can think about it later, this should work for now

Anyone know of the easiest way to do that?
